summary: Director Hideaki Anno's conclusion to the landmark anime series.

reviews.content: This is cinema. The peak fiction from peak fiction from Hideaki Anno, with a an amazing ending for the 1997's series.
This was an absolute masterpiece

Warning: Spoilers
The story of Neon Genesis Evangelion is a simple one. Its the story of a young man who takes on the responsibilities of saving the world and has to deal with the consequences of not trusting people.

Of not letting them in

If I go into massive amounts of detail here, it would ruin the impact of this story and its far more worth it to experience the series in its entirety

So I suggest you watch the TV series, the last 2 episodes and then this movie, back to back as much as you can.

Remembering one thing about all the characters you're seeing and loving.

They are liars and they ALL hate themselves on some level. Don't trust what they TELL YOU, trust what they SHOW YOU in their actions.

By doing that, when you get to the pivotal scene of "help me" you'll begin to understand what is going on.

Pray for the poor people who suffer like these souls. And trust they'll be okay if you reach out to them.

On its own, End of Evangelion gives to the fanbase every tiny little bit of what it wanted, it isn't what we THOUGHT want wanted, but its what we wanted.

And you should listen to what Rei is saying...and then realise that she's not just saying it to Shinji, she's saying it to EVERYONE - including you.

I have to walk back a worlds worth of bile and hatred of Hideki Anno for the things that I said about the Rebuilds, the man is not a hack or a fool.

He's always been a tortured genius Watch his work. Love it and spread the message he's giving.
Amazing ending to a masterpiece of a series.

The "end."  I seriously doubt I can recap an entire complex television series in a concise plot synopsis, so let me just say that this is the ending to the anime for the fans that were not satiated by the final two episodes.  Now with this one, I will try to avoid going into extensive specifics regarding what this is about because I don't feel like it would be a great use of everyone's time.  It's a stupendous show that you should watch even if you don't have a background in anime.  There is mystery and intrigue around every story turn, and when you combine that with colossal robots, monsters, and fantastic production values, you've got yourself quite a show.  Now that I've finally wrapped the series, I'll be taking on the movies, which has always been a point of confusion for me.  My good friend has been walking me through the episodes every step of the way, and even after multiple conversations, I still don't think I will have a chronological grasp on the movies until I actually watch them.  If they are at all close in quality to this movie here, then I've got a lot to look forward to.  An interesting point of this movie is that it only exists because creator Hideaki Anno essentially got bullied into making it.  This doesn't spoil much, but the last two episodes of the series drop the main running story and opt to get completely introspective.  While I didn't mind them going that route, I understood why fans were upset about it.  That's not to justify the death threats that Anno received, I'm just saying that I get it.  As far as the actual movie goes, this is basically two extended episodes combined into one, and I'm not exaggerating when I say that there are credits at the midpoint, which is not something I've seen before (unless you're counting Drive my Car).  The first half is truly something else.  I'm having difficulty referencing a movie that has more feel-bad action than the first half that this movie pulls off.  It's an outnumbered siege situation, and casualties are happening left and right on both sides.  This makes it so that while the smooth action is as jaw-dropping as it has ever been in this entire series, you can't relish in it because it immediately slams you back down to Earth with a gut punch.  The second half of this movie gets back to the metaphysical, which stays more in step with the controversial last two episodes of the series.  If that's what you're here for, great.  Personally, I felt like the second half would pair better with a Wikipedia article, but it does get by on the strength of its visuals, which are nothing short of stunning.  This is absolutely not for outsiders.  I don't know why you would, but if you're trying to watch this without having first experienced the series, you will be like a child lost in a shopping mall (back when malls were still a thing).  This is strictly for the fans of the series, and it does not disappoint.  It's a bit difficult for me to rate because it feels like I'm grading the entire series as opposed to a standalone movie.  I may come back and change my rating later if I feel so inclined, but as it stands, this is a highly satisfying conclusion that will both answer burning questions and raise new ones.
Absolute masterpiece but only really makes sense if you watched the show

Hideaki Anno is focused too much on making big philosophical nonsense, pretentious imagery, and meta-criticism directed toward the viewers instead of a coherent and believable story. Anno is so adamant on concluding the story on a forced miserable tone. Gone are the character interactions from the series, particularly among the three pilots. Even Rei Ayanami has less personality than in the series, being reduced to an object. Whereas the original ending of the series simply abandoned the main story, this film is misguided in its attempt to end the story.
It was an absolute masterpiece you shouldn't miss it

Warning: Spoilers
Finally, after long last, I have managed to watch the End of Evangelion. It was worth any wait.

Those not familiar with the series will have no clue what's happening, so you should at least watch the first 24 episodes. End of Eva takes place as an alternative to the last 25 and 26th episodes. It may sound confusing, but trust me, if you just sit back and enjoy the ride, everything makes sense...even if not right away.

The final Angel has been killed. The 'hero' of the story, Shinji Ikari, now regrets doing it, as he was the only person who seemed to ever like him for who he was. But there is no time to lament on personal demons, as the shadowy puppet masters in SEELE have set the final stage of their plan in motion.

The dreaded Third Impact.

What's even more surprising is that the entire series shows one, giant plan to actually SPEED ALONG the Third Impact, as it could lead Humanity to it's next evolutionary step.

And so, Humanity will now rely on a weak savior who may or may not lead humanity to it's oblivion. A hero who must first fight his own inner dragons, and come to terms with life, and love from himself and from others.

As a response to the public outcry that the last 2 episodes were someone strange and had no "Mecha Combat", the End of Eva has enough of both combat, AND philosophical scenes. A strange, but wonderful mix.

Asuka's fight against 9 Evas is absolutely the most STUNNING visual fight sequence I have ever seen. The energy and awesome scope of the battle is impossible to convey through words alone.

Though Asuka's character is as flawed as Shinji's, she finds redemption in this movie. Again, an amazing testimony of the Human Spirit and our will to live.

The emotional impact of this movie is also quite amazing. It brings reality and the mind to question, and asks us if being individuals is better than being a whole. Is life just a dream, and can we ever be Gods of our own Reality? Those who have watched the last two episodes of the series will see instances where the movie and episodes combine and compliment each other.

Finally, the animation is wonderful. Creepy and breathtaking. Powerfully deep, but also amazing on the physical conflict level as well. This movie is EASILY a match for Akira and is an instant classic.

Watch it with an open mind, and be prepared to be stunned. Be ready to question yourself. Be ready to use your mind in ways you may have not before. This is truly the End, and I wouldn't want it any other way.

Possibly the most disturbing movie I have ever seen, the story is fine but the execution is nightmare fuel. The entire movie gives off an unsettling feeling, like something is wrong, the whole thing is wrong.
A perfect conclusion to the story of Evangelion.

Although there are... questionable parts that could use a bit more explaining, the message of the scene shines through the weirdness. It was an absolute delight being able to conclude this series, especially in such a fantastic way. The colors used, the music, and emotion conveyed through the characters makes this an incredible movie to watch. Although the original ending of Neon Genesis Evangelion was good enough, this completely elevates it, and I wish I could go back in time to watch this movie again. This is one of the greatest pieces of fictions I've been able to experience.
probably my favourite movie, amazing imagery, amazingly written characters, great soundtrack, beautiful ending

There is nothing quite like Neon Genesis Evangelion. From its dialogue to its characters to its direction, there is this insurmountable, incomprehensible anxiety that follows everything and everyone in the franchise. The End of Evangelion is the amalgamation of this feeling. This is a movie experience too important, and too complex, to be put into words. If you are willing to be genuinely changed by a movie experience, for better or for worse, please watch this. You will not regret it.

10/10
A cinematic master piece that demands rewatching to fully digest the many interpretations of the ending of one of the greatest anime of all times

Again, just like the end of the anime show, it's shrouded in mystery and weirdness. But wow, the animations and art are a step above the show. It looks cleaner and way more polished. It's beautiful, and kinetically stylized! It also starts out notably dark with the infiltration of NERV. A lot more bloodier and violent as well. But it makes sense since it's the End of Evangelion. 

Omg the A.T. fields that protect the Eva's and Angels are actually a loved ones spirit that is shielding them! In the case of Shinji and Asuka, it's their deceased mother's soul who has inhabited their Eva's. That's beautifully poetic. Holy shit that introduction of the 9 white Eva's was incredible. They look really deadly! 

One of the most exciting and thrilling anime's I've ever watched with some of the most brilliant animations. Some of its premise is very fucking weird but it also makes for some very intriguing and original material to watch. The imagery in this movie is much more ominous and darker than the show. The themes can be somewhat depressing especially towards the end of the series and especially during the movie, as it dwells a lot on loneliness and isolation from others. It makes sense when you realize that the director was battling with depression throughout the making of it. He read a book on depression that changed his outlook and is the reason why the anime took such a weird turn during the last couple of episodes. But overall, I thought it was one of the most visually dazzling and kinetic anime's I've ever seen. With some of the most brilliant and original ideas about the human self I've ever seen an anime tackle. Evangelion is an anime that is in a league of its own. This is definitely worth watching!
Worst piece of shit I've ever seen
A wonderful twist to the TV series ending that fits better with what fans were expecting from Hideaki Anno. Beautiful music and anime.

Let me summarize this movie: the mc Shinji does nothing but scream throught the whole film, while having an existential crisis.  Everyone around him have to carry the film for him while some of the main characters die around him. As Asuka stated in the film; pathetic!
This movie is a masterpiece of the mecha anime. I love how Hideaki Anno projects youth population depression in the film and ends the end of the anime in the best way.

One of the masterpieces of animation, it shows an outstanding animation, edition and script even 24 years later.
All this combined with the most surrealistic and memorable visuals in the series.

The full excess of everything its creator wanted in his vision entirely. The animation is incredible, the imagery is euphoric, and it is unlike any animated film of it's kind. A satisfying conclusion with an ending that boggles the mind but intrigued all at once.

A gorgeously animated and tragic film that delivers on being a finale to the show that led up to it. End of Evangelion resolves the conflicts and themes of the series in a disturbing and cryptic ending that leaves you thinking after you've finished it, puzzled by it's symbolism that was hinted since the beginning

My favourite movie up to this date. Hideaki Anno's work shows themes of depression, individuality, self identity crises, and much more. The visuals and soundtrack of this movie were definitely amazing which makes it a must see!

The finale of "Neon Genesis Evangelion" delivers what fans of the series would come to expect. The movie is a strange one that shows more questions than answers by the end but is fascinating to watch. The first half of the movie is straightforward and visually stirring exciting sequences but it evolves into something more ambiguous and open-ended. I think the movie is about as good as the series, which I also enjoyed watching recently. Overall, it is a solid, puzzling, but also very deep and thought-provoking finale with many striking visual moments.
The best part of the Evangelion experience.
This movie is a masterpiece of animation

This film was, overall, not an enjoyable experience the first time watching. If you watched Neon Genesis Evangelion, became attached to the characters, and wanted to see them win their happy ending, then you're better off sticking with Episode 26's comparatively calm and poetic conclusion. This film is DESTRUCTIVE. But if you're prepared to live with that, by all means, please make this your definitive conclusion of the series.
made 0 sense, disgusting sexualization of minors
One of the best anime movies of all time.

I half-heartedly watched it, I wanted to give myself more time to process the end of the TV show but I needed the closure. So I got impatient.

By the end of the film all I wanted to do was call my mum to ask her to fly over and get me hot cocoa. That was so bleak. Whereby the TV show had a faint hopeful note, this was essentially someone deciding to have you drowned, burned and the quartered... Then fed to the pigs. 

It almost felt like I was being punished for wanting to know what happened to the other people that were part of the story. Like I was being told "...You just couldn't let it go, could you?" 

I regret watching it but at the same time I cannot deny that it was well done. I would urge people to sit on the ending of the TV show for longer before actually deciding to go in for the kill which was that film.

As an ending to the greatest tv show ever, they decided to create the greatest movie ever. Watching everything fall apart has never been more cathartic and Shinji's revelation gives an optimistic ending even through all the pain.
You don't need to hate the show's ending to appreciate this movie.

9.1. End of Evangelion is able to capture an alternate ending towards the story of NGE, and while it keeps many things vague and questionable, it, personally, is a much better completion to the story. While the original last two episodes only seeked to dive into Shinji's struggle with the instrumentality project, EoE gives an overarching story that satisfies many more questions within the series. Ultimately, while both endings serve their purpose, EoE ends the storyline with a much more fragile ideal of life and death itself.
No words can describe the thing that I just saw
I have seen all of it and......IT WAS CRAP THE S,.loplw.........——-

This movie may be confusing as heck and have a bunch of symbols and things that don't make sense but to me it is art.  I loved this movie and I really like how it perfectly ended a great cartoon with pretty good animation from the 90s.  However there is only one thing I did not like at all about this movie and it was the part where Shinji was playing in a Sandbox for 10 minutes.  Or was that scene in the finale of the cartoon NO that had more hentai.

Incredible, and a fitting end to the series. I wouldn't recommend watching if you're the kind of person who wants everything spelled out to them, gets frustrated with strange avant garde elements, or needs a happy ending. It's certainly not for everyone. That being said, if you think this is your niche, you'll likely watch it countless times just trying to get a better understanding, and you'll enjoy it every time. Excellent directing, a great story, and perhaps the best written characters I've ever seen. Despite it's widespread popularity, it seems incredibly like an art house film through and through.
Without consciousness or unknowns neither happiness nor pain can exist. This movie puts asserts that experience is worth experiencing.
A fitting end. But some points in the 2nd act suffers from problems the original series ending had.
Ehhh... What the hell did I watch?

The End of Evangelion makes use of its deeply complex narrative, unique art direction, and masterful animation to staple itself as an animated film that is unlike any other. As an individual piece of cinematic art, it can be described as something that is both horrifying yet beautiful; as well as  heartbreaking yet satisfying.

A piece of art from head to toe, an incredible closure for a great cult series along with a great intrigue and emotional charge.

In the end, true love triumphs, heterosexual love of course.

If you are English speaking, you probably did not understand the reference.
loved it, nothing makes me feel the way this movie does.
The best thing ive ever seen in my life.
End of Evangelion is a more satisfying but no less mystifying conclusion to a great series.
A great ending to a great series.  Loved it.
A final better than Tv series. The movie talks about a very deep aspectos of your time and represent a time when was maded that even now it's important
Truly amazing! I recommend this to anyone who's a fan of the original series.
Not as good as the series, but it was still a pretty spectacular film that was also a great conclusion to NGE.

UHHHHH...That was, that was...okay...I need time to process that... Anyway, there's some great animation and action. Its ideas can be fascinating (in a certain sense it is a subversion of Cosmic Horror or the anti-Weird). But, Shinji masturbates to completion over Asuka's comatose body...Yeah...It is messy, bleak, and hard to deny that it is in part revenge against the otaku community (especially for the way otaku culture objectifies women).
A mind fucker of anime history.

An insane, incredible, visually striking and highly emotional experience. Some of the philosophy presented in this film is almost overwhelming. Truly beautiful, shocking, horrifying, and astounding. There is no film quite like this. There may never be.
Greatest movie ever.
A cinematographic masterpiece that could have only been done in japan by Gainax in it's prime and a depressed Hiddeki Anno.
A great and somewhat confusing end to the NGE series that plunges you into madness and turmoil as you try to find a way out of insanity.
Deep, beautiful, and confusing as ****, but it leaves a satisfying conclusion to the Evangelion series.

Animation reaching it's ultimate cinematic peak, my 18 years of living have not prepared me for this...
"It all returns to nothing, it all comes tumbling down, tumbling down, tumbling down..."
A gigantic mess of themes, metaphors, imagery, emotions, events, action and so much more make for a remarkably awesome conclusion to the TV series
One of the best films of all time.
Quite simply my favorite movie. :)
the greatest post-apocalypse film of all time (next to angel's egg)

OKay, I am an Asuka fan and I am here to complain about Asuka and how she got pushed to the sidelines. She is my favorite character and I don't like what they did to her. It was too torturous, they ruined her eye and her Eva REALLY BADLY and Shinji just got even more hateful by going crazy, crying, and even choking her at the end (gladly, she didn't die).

I do not get the hype for this. The movie is boring. Asuka is what made the series better, I would've got bored and I did skip the episodes if she wasn't in them. So, I guess I do not get this movie or maybe I have to watch the series again.

So, now we got to suffer an hour of Shinji's pansy butt. Like in the series, he did get more likable towards the end when we learn about his past. I did like Misato more, too. Rei had a more decent ark, but I don't like the end of the world thing at the end. No one else I really could care much for.

This movie was just creepy and violent. I was thinking that this would be a great film but it was just very over-hyped. This movie just had me screaming at the computer through. The characters are quite different, Asuka is worrying about her mother and I was wondering if like I heard, it may be because her mother's soul was there or she was just relying on her to try her best to get through this hard battle but she had a really evil face on sometimes during the battle, I understand that this type of facial expression was new for its time but it still looked too evil. Misato seemed to have been in love with Shinji, she might've been this way in the series, too. And I don't understand Rei's arc of being above the world while it was destroyed.

I also did not like the new facial expressions for Asuka representing the scenes in the anime like when she wakes Shinji up, she's now more scary and hateful than she was likable and funny.

I also do not like the live-action combination in this, even though it did have a good message about reality in dreams.

The jazzy song at the end of the first half was okay but it was smoother than Fly Me To The Moon.

Gladly, it did not have Hikari in it but it still could do better than this.
The most mindblowing anime I've ever seen, one of the most mindblowing films period for that matter.
Just keep tumbling down, tumbling down, tumbling down!

I did the legendary franchise "Neon Genesis Evangelion" a disservice by watching this film first. Due to my time constraint and the lengthy and complex nature of the franchise, I decided to take a shortcut and watch this film first to "get the spirit" of the whole series. It turned out horribly wrong when I did not get anything from this film, except for its exceptional visual and soundtrack (the predominant use of classical music in battle sequences, especially the "Battle Royale"'s "Air on G-String" is suffocatingly amazing). My only lesson learned from this film is that you should approach a high concept series full of existentialist, religious, and philosophical implications, from its base, not from its top. See you next time, "Neon Genesis Evangelion".

Completely disregard episodes 25 and 26 of the television series.  They are not the true ending and not a satisfying ending.  End of Evangelion is the true ending as the creators intended.  It is crazy and sometimes nonsensical, but that is okay.  The imagery is beautiful, the characters are deep, and the action is top notch.  I highly recommend the TV series up to episode 24, then watch this movie for the conclusion.

Aaand finished. At least until the next version of things comes out. I feel as if the director/creator should maybe stop tinkering with these, but the overall story arc going from typical robot battles to existential dramas is intriguing nonetheless.

Recommended.

Even with the absurd amount of hype I had for this film, nothing can adequately prepare you for what you are about to witness as it is completely unpredictable. I try to go into every film without any expectations but after everything that I've heard about this, it was quite hard not to go in with expectations. Saying that, The End of Evangelion is a rather unsettling experience that never lets up all the way until the final scene.

It's quite hard to review something like this, I've been thinking about this for a long time and I'm finding it increasingly difficult to write anything. It isn't as simple as sitting down for 90 minutes and writing about what you saw, objectively. This film is more about how you interpret it for yourself and coming to your own conclusions for what it all means, very much of it I think I understand but some other parts just mystify me. 

At the end of episode 24 of the anime they show clips from this, so that means that they were working on this for well over 2 years and it really does show. The animation is absolutely beautiful and it is very smooth, the action is exhilarating and the imagery that appears near the end is unforgettable. I very much like that it is technically split into two halves one as it does keep it the same as the anime but it flows like a film because of the extended length of the halves. It doesn't at all feel like something that should have gone to TV. Both parts are directed perfectly and it is seamless but it's only fitting to have Anno direct part II. The credits are in the middle and it's like a warning, a warning to the audience to leave now because everything after that point just goes south fast. 

As harsh as this sounds, I'm glad this ran into problems when this was intended for broadcast on the TV, only because I feel like if it was allowed, a lot of what made this what it is would most definitely have been taken out and it would have in turn, dampened the impact. While I don't hate the ending of the anime and you could say both endings happened in one way or another, this certainly has a lot more weight to it and is most definitely more memorable and fits better with the dark tone of the series. The scenes toward the end are so vivid and visceral that I don't think any of it would be allowed to be broadcast and the anime already pushed a few boundaries as it is. Of course, however, if this was left on TV it's not like we'd notice any difference because we wouldn't have anything else to compare it to. However, it does feel like something that belongs in a film and the budget problems that plagued the series and it's finale are nowhere to be seen here and once again, the animation shines. They did an amazing job with what they had in the series and this is just brilliant.

Shinji Ikari still remains one of the most fascinating characters I think I've ever seen. I kept waiting for that pivotal moment in the anime where his character would develop into someone that isn't as afraid anymore but after talking with a friend, I just came to the realisation that, that was never going to happen. It's so strange to see a character in a work of fiction who is the same at the end as he was in the beginning and you could even argue that he is worse in the end of this. It might end up being annoying to some that while he has plenty of development, he doesn't really change but life doesn't alway work out in a nice 3 act structure of people overcoming their fears, sometimes it doesn't happen. Sometimes he's annoying, sometimes he's infuriating, sometimes he's likeable, sometimes he's not, he's just a fantastic character. I don't think we're supposed to like him 100% of the time and while that can be a problem of storytelling, wherein, if the main character isn't likeable then the show becomes annoying, I do think it works well with this series and gives it a whole new dimension and any character that has me yelling at the screen has to be doing something right. And to be honest, I see part of myself in Shinji, I've been like he has before, not as bad as he has but there are definitely some parts that ring home and it only makes it all the more relevant and probably a reason why I like him more than most do. When I say that him not changing is a good thing, I'm not trying to make excuses for a bad character and say that it's really deep because it's unique that he doesn't change because it isn't like that, you'd need to watch the entire series to understand fully what I mean. The rest of the characters still remain as brilliantly written as ever and all the original voice actors return.

If I have to find any complaint at all its that I think some scenes could have benefited with less music being played in the background and just let the sound effects of the scene set the mood, instead of being told what to feel by the blaring music in the background. Also, I got a little bored in the live action parts of the film, I understand their point and why they are there, it just took me out of the experience for a little bit, but now I see where MGS 2 got a little inspiration. Saying that, these aren't a big enough negative to take away any of the impact that this film holds. 

This review took a long time to write and it's probably one of the reviews I've agonised over the most. The longer I sit here and think about this film and the anime, the greater it gets. It really isn't hard to see why this series has been as influential as it has been and there is nothing else quite like it. The End of Evangelion is a shocking, emotionally devastating experience with some of the most creative animation I think I've ever seen. It asks plenty of questions, leaves many things up in the air for a long time and explains very little of it (if at all) and just ends, that might be annoying to some but I think it's fantastic. And it'll probably take a few more watches, of both anime and film, to piece it all together and understand it all because of reveals that happen in both anime and film. There was nothing like it before and there probably won't be ever again. It's amazing. Oh, and just because for a joke, 2deep4u... Hopefully someone gets that. Haha.
Easily one of if not the greatest animated film ever made.
A masterpiece from top to bottom. Never before has a film taken me through such a roller coaster of emotions, and never will it be topped.
message of hope.. or not..?
It certainly isn't for everybody and it could be a little confusing, but personally I found it  to be a  fantastic and worthy conclusion to the series.
The greatest film I've ever seen.
a lot of science fiction about judgement day,apocalypse.Worth watching
This was better then a lot of the episodes of the anime were. Gave it a unique ending not that I fully understood it.
the series gets 5 stars even with the crazy train ending
I'll first state that i'm not an anime person. Haven't seen many but my friends have seen tons. So I gave the series as well as this film a watch. I didn't regret it.

The psychological conflict is heartfelt, and the director's psyche split right open for the world to not only see, but also experience. This was the conclusion of something special, yet very disturbing. It's unfathomable, yet perfectly understandable, why the Neon Genesis Evangelion anime is so acclaimed and was such an propelling engine to the popularization of anime in general - especially when considering the fact that all the characters are so miserable. It's hard to not recommend the anime + movie to anyone when considering the underlying psychological experience viewers might go through - or even suffer through. One thing is for sure though, and that is that the series was masterfully crafted.
Both disturbing and confusing like a visual roller coaster of terror, but it has to be seen to be believed.
one of my favourite anime movies, amazing
Mind blowing. This one hit me like a surprise left hook.

One of the most infamous anime movies ever made, End of Evangelion is still a FAR more satisfying ending than the ambiguously horrendously atrocious anime finale, adding action, intensity, and absolute strangeness

A beautifully frightening ode to humanity's problems, an excellent closer to one of the best television shows of all time, and a masterpiece of mainstream surrealism this side of David Lynch, "End of Evangelion" hits both intellectual and visceral levels in such a way that it hurts to watch the film as it is. With beautifully minimalist animation, great screenwriting, and some of the most original imagery created from the mind of an unstable man, "End of Evangelion" is a testament to the power of the human will and Hideaki Anno's own creative mind.

The question is: why don't more mainstream Hollywood films look up to this?

Oh, wait. Because it's anime and all anime is tentacle porn.
A movie considered gold by some and garbage by others, it's one of those films whose rating depends purely on the viewer. Personally, I love it.

The "Outside" version of the final episodes of NGE is put into movie form, it's gruesome. It's heavy. And it's wildly confusing. Once you can sort out the tendrils here and piece the information together you can have a true understanding of what is a rich and great character driven story (The entire series, not just this film) but it is so dense, an unfocused mind will be assuredly lost, and a squeamish mind will falter on the graphic scenes in the film and  even the series. In the end this is effective and accomplishes what it set out to do even if it has its share of mis steps.
Highly controversial and highly entertaining.
I thought this was a less "sick" ending to events depicted in the TV series but I was very wrong. I have no idea how to rate this stuff!
the horror in the movie and the movie music represented how the movie should feel and it can be cofusing at times even if you watched the series

I was gasping for air after watching this. The only thing I could do to express how this made me feel was curl up in a ball and cry to myself silently. Never has something made me question my reality and everything I held true than this masterpiece and cinematic even that truly, change my life. Watch the series first tho.
Nonsensical, disturbing and unsatisfying conclusion to the story of a series that best served as a template to the more entertaining "Digimon Tamers".

The End of Evangelion finally provides a coherent ending/finale -- maybe not so in general but yeah much clearer than the the ones in the original anime. But i'm not taking anything out of the original finale, it is indeed a clever examination of the characters and their psyche. 

This one shows the apocalyptic visions of Anno unfolding and the several loopholes and secrets that were puzzling the fans from the original anime being revealed. Therefore the entire movie plays out with all hell breaking loose. There are huge explosions with SEELE initiating the operation to totally take over NERV, where we are shown hand to hand combat sequences as well as mecha fights involving Unit-002 and the several hastily built other Evas. It is captivating at the same time spectacular. 

There are well-though out endings to the characters, though some of them are less fulfilling. Evangelion escalates into a massive struggle, but this the end result seems predeterined and inevitable but there is always Shinji there to save the day. He is seen answering and contemplating a lot of profound questions regarding his mental states as well as those which will determine the future of mankind as abstract images are super-imposed over one another to create a collage and surreal effect.

It end very ambiguously but nevertheless it did it succeed in it's primary goal, i.e. to culminate the seires and to fill our all the loopholes and unanswered questions that had arosen in Neon Genesis.

A masterpiece in every way and the true end that the Evangelion series and it's fans deserved. Only with the Rebuild of Evangelion films would Hideaki Anno finally show us his true vision in all of it's beautifully animated glory. 5 out of 5 Stars.
This movie was absolutely insane. I mean, sure it made sense in the context of the lore, but wow, it was ridiculously mind melting.

It's not for everyone, that's for sure. The movie is more than a masterpiece, it's a piece of art. Goes as much deeper in the human existence subject as well as offering a more climatic, convincing ending to one of the best animes ever made.

While the ending of the series managed to close circles with character Shinji, the rest was left out. How did the Instrumentality happen? What could happen next? What the fuck was happening? All answers are here, in The End of Evangelion. The story centers around an overly depressed Shinji, and how his desires, hatred, and all kinds of emotions ultimately has consequences in what could be the World's End (and with it, our possible rebirth) or the future of humanity. The movie has great animation, amazing visuals, great shots and all kinds of cryptic and symbolical sequences that not every person will understand. That's the issue with many people in this movie, they don't get anything of what's going on. Well, of course you have to watch the entire series to understand and have an eye and mind for symbolism and religion.

This movie has many things that make it work: the ambientation gives the feeling that the end is near, and somehow, we are there. And also, we know is coming, it could happen any time, by any cirmustance. The movie has a very climatic, emotional and character circles coming to close scene, were we see all humans dying and transforming into one sole being. The movie is fantastic. The music and songs just fits so perfectly, and the sequences and dialogue are so intriguing that it's impossible to forget this movie. This is a perfect ending for a great anime like Neon Genesis Evangelion; it closes everything and also leaves a huge space for interpretation, such like the final scene:

Shinji is alone in a red beach, full of LCL (the human being without soul or form) with Asuka, the girl he constantly pleeded for. Shinji sees a ghostly Rei (like in the first episode of the series) that suddenly dissapears. The he sees Asuka, wounded but apparently fine. And then...he strangles her. This in order to prove "a human emotion", to prove that both are separated from the united existence of the humans (turned into LCL); by Asuka rejecting Shinji, like she always do. However, instead, she caresses his face. The last line is by her words: "How disgusting". And the story of Evangelion ends.

Wow, now that's and ending only a true fan could understand and be OK with. A nearly-perfect ending that satysfies. Ultimately the point of this ending is not let the ending as it was written, instead give a solid basis for the fans to create their own conclusions: there's no concrete ending for this story, it depends on the fan, he or she can interpretate it the way they want; if it's a happy ending, a sad one, a mystical one, or every kind of finale you can think, it depends on you. I thought that was very ingenious, that way everyone can have the ending they want. It's confusing, but not for me, i know every scene, every line, leads to the perfect finale of a perfect series. Probably the deepest movie i have watched.

Now, before I even bother to write this review I'd like to address what at least some of you are thinking. 'Why the hell is there 5 stars next to an anime on your list?' And not just an anime either, is what I'd reaffirm for you, but the movie ending of an anime series. Heresy, right? Well... Probably. But here's the thing. Very few movies can match this opus visually, tonally, atmospherically, or in character. For the ambition of this project and bravery of the director alone this should get five stars.

To explain what makes this film so special requires me to go into moderate, to in-depth detail about the television series and subsequently this movie. Because this is unavoidable, this review will completely disregard any attempt to avoid spoilers. So if you haven't seen the television series and this film, please just stop here, go rent it or whatever and watch. The rest of you, please carry on.

Now, if my warning was heeded, this review should really only be being read by people who've seen the film and thus one would imagine would be completely aware of what Neon Genesis Evangelion is, but bear with me while I scribble this little introduction and synopsis anyway. Neon Genesis Evangelion is a 26 episode anime released in the mid-90s by Gainex studio. Directed by Hideaki Anno, who subsequently moved on after Evangelion to direct live action cinema, Evangelion will be remember by many anime historians, should there be such a thing, as a revolution. The series fearlessly tackled with issues of existentialism, identity, depression, faith, religion, alienation, and sexuality amongst other things, and here's the important bit, it did so through the lens of the genre. Evangelion didn't shy away from giant robots, hypersexualised females and whacky Japanese humour; in fact, it downright embraces the conventions expected of anime. And this leaves us with something one couldn't expect. An oddity, a bizarre amalgamation of everything distinctly pulp, which one will typically scoff at, with this genuine exploration of the human condition- a feat 'real cinema' should always aspire to. And there's more.

Some have suggested Evangelion wasn't always intended to be what it was. Gainax, the studio behind the development, was close to sinking under a tidal wave of financial problems at the time, and slowly but surely they began chopping Evangelion's budget until it was close to nonexistent. To add to the difficulties of the production, the writer-director, Hideaki Anno, was struck by a black depression, a darkness which is known to have consumed him during the production. It is said the combination of the budget cuts and the dejection Anno was experiencing forced the series in a much starker, more experimental, direction. The first few episodes of the series contain no hint of the bleak tone that permeates the conclusion of the series. But it is in this perhaps unprecedented shift in tone that the luster lies. One grows to have certain expectation from any genre, and Evangelion at the beginning fits the mould of an anime perfectly. We have big robots, sexualised females, an unwilling 14 year old boy and a quest to save the city. So as the pace of the episodes begins to slow, and we are presented with internal monologues, characters questioning their existence, metaphysical symbolism, and suddenly we're being asked to no longer think of these behemoth robots as mere fighting tools, but as a metaphorical representation of the characters' will and the impending doom is no longer odd looking aliens, but trials the teenagers face in their lives we are flung. We become invested. Which of course only makes it harder to accept the inevitable, as the characters fall into what becomes more and more obviously a hopeless end. Or does it? We reach episodes 25 and 26, the most surrealist and experimental episodes of the series, to be left only with ambiguity. Did the kids survive? Was the world saved? It's all left to interpretation. 

Now all of that is an examination on a thematic level. I haven't even bothered to write about how the score is unrivalled in terms of anime, how the character designs have become iconic, how beautiful the animation is, how Anno creates a genuinely intriguing mystery, or how the action scenes ramp up the tension to unbearable heights. Mainly because without the thematic depths, these aspects would just make it a brilliant anime. And that would not be what it in fact is- which is a film worthy of five stars. Now I know some of you may still think it's a cheat, because let's face it, I'm basically reviewing this as an extension of the TV series rather than a stand alone film. So anyone criticising my review on that basis, I will yield and hold my hands up. Ignoring that, I stand by everything I've written!

Now onto the actual film. The End of Evangelion. The film as you're all no doubt aware is split very clearly into two halves. But before we delve into that, let's discuss how the film came into existence in the first place. So it's now 1997, a year and a bit after the last episode of the series has aired in Japan. The series has rescued Gainax (and has provided quite the cash cow even until this day, with a 'retelling' of the series receiving a 4 film theatrical release internationally) and proven a huge hit. Happy ending for Anno? No. Although Evangelion prove itself critically and commercially, fans were outraged at the ending. Gainax was inundated with complaints from furious fans demanding a 'proper' ending, and Anno himself received countless death threats. Seems anime fans weren't too appreciative of surrealism. For whatever reason, the unreasonable demands were met. Perhaps Anno relented or perhaps Gainax saw a great opportunity to milk the cow that secreted gold. Either way, 'The End of Evangelion' was commissioned and released. Not only this, but it took into account the fans complaints. Not enough action? That'll be remedied. More 'fan service' (an odious addition in anime catering to the otaku among viewers... Look it up)? Sure thing.

The first half of The End of Evangelion culminates in the massacre of the entire cast, whilst the main character, 14 year old Shinji, whom fans should have grown to care for, masturbates over the comatose naked body of Asuka, his 14 year old friend. Careful what you wish for, I guess. If anywhere else in cinema a director has been as brazen in his contempt for his fan-base I'm unaware of it. This description may make the film sound reactionary and artless, but quite in fact everything that happens seems to merely present the ending of the TV series in a more literal manner. The only difference is, where there was some ambiguity left in the final scenes of the series, here all hope is removed. The melancholy is relentless. The effect of this ending remains with me to this day, 10 years after first seeing it- the emotions it evoked as fresh on reflection as they were on first viewing. The second half of the film becomes hallucinogenic. The direction becomes deconstructionist, literally erasing layer after layer of animation until we have reverted to the beginning of the process, which has a powerful impact considering the events taking place. There is no longer any artifice or veneer, the viewer is seeing the half-formed mess at the core of Shinji's soul, his true will and all of the ambivalence he feels. The film finishes, as a last middle finger to the fans, as unknowable as the television series, but with a much more melancholic, despairing shade.

And that's it. The End Of Evangelion and why it is nothing short of brilliant. I've specifically avoided any real interpretation, because as a true Evangelion fan, I know how subjective and meaningful each person's individual take is.
This film is very good however it is very complex.

Surprisingly, this Shinji-external perception of the "Neon Genesis Evangelion" conclusion is almost as unsatisfying as its series counterpart, playing like a philosophical text as it moves between its ideas with a great amount of abstract depth, paralleled by a plot which leaves behind many loose ends and concludes with a confounding lack of closure in its despairing, anti-climactic ending. What makes "The End of Evangelion" perhaps one of the greatest, or at least noteworthy pieces in anime history, is that it turns the above aspects--faults in most's eyes--into immense strengths. Concluding a fairly straightforward series on a mind-blowing, provocative and insightful note, "The End of Evangelion" leaves the viewer mentally and emotionally decomposed, as well as pleasantly disappointed by its lack of closure. In addition to visual extravagance and overwhelming writing, the film will undoubtedly leave behind an overflow of replay and discussion value, and so it is advised that one should view this film immediately after completing the series, and with at least one friend.

A visually stunning conclusion to the original "Neon Genesis Evangelion" anime series. Disgruntled fans of the original TV show hounded director Hideaki Anno for ending the show with a cliffhanger. Anno, dealing with depression and frustrated by the pressure being placed on him provided an end to the series: a shocking, horrifying but strangely satisfying ending.
The story revolves around the 14-year old pilots of giant, living warrior/machines called Evas. They protect Tokyo from mysterious creatures known as the Angels, whose purpose for attacking the city have been, up until this movie, purported to be the destruction of humankind. 
My synopsis is greatly oversimplified. The series has a deep, multilayered plot with Freudian and religious symbols strewn throughout. The characters are fleshed out almost too much; we frequently see the turmoil going on inside the main character's head as exposition.
This film revolves around the theme of human nature. All of the characters' deepest and darkest desires and compulsions are explored in ways not usually seen in animated films. Because of this, there is a lot of disturbing imagery. The apocalyptic events portrayed in the film complement the characters' heart-wrenching struggles as their sins, neuroses and shortcomings are laid bare. And there's plenty of fantasy action to make up for the more understated scenes that take place in the characters' minds.
Moviegoers not familiar with the original TV show may not appreciate this film, as it relies on a load of foreknowledge about the technobabble and situations. The visualizations, however are striking enough by themselves to be lauded for ingenuity. I fall short in being able to convey the power of these visuals. The director even sneaks in seconds of footage containing images of letters written to him by disgruntled fans. I believe the best way to describe the visuals is post-modern.
The music, by Shiro Sagisu is powerful, and it was nominated for several awards in Japan. The soundtrack as a stand-alone CD is fresh and exciting as well.
According to the amazon.com descriptions of the DVD, this film has been rated NC-17 (sometimes "unrated") because of sexual situations involving 14-year-olds and graphic violence. This is not a "cartoon" in the traditional sense. Adults I know who have seen this film have admitted to me that they were a bit disturbed by the movie. It is a troubling, perhaps cynical, view of mankind and its future portrayed through animation. It is by no means preachy, though. I advise moviegoers to avoid this movie if they might be offended by graphic sexual scenes, twisted portrayals of Judeo-Christian symbols and gory battles. Otherwise, it's a movie experience like no other I've ever seen. 4/5 stars.

Even the DVD Menu Is Seriously Weird  

Last night, I was discussing anime with a friend.  She says she likes the kind where all the main characters have something seriously wrong in their minds, so I assume she's a fan of [i]Eva[/i].  But anyway, we were observing how anime theme songs never, ever seem to connect to the actual tone and action of the show they're about.  I mean, [i]Ranma 1/2[/i] has the "yapapa!" song, which is at least cheerful and silly, but mostly, it seems that theme songs are chosen at random.  They're also usually love songs of some sort, even if there isn't much in the way of romance to the story or if what romance there is fails to be the primary focus of the show.  And then today, I was watching this, and the theme music seems to imply that this is a very different kind of anime than it is.  It can be argued that the theme of [i]Eva[/i] is Shinji's becoming a man, but not in the sense the theme music implies.

This is an alternate ending to the TV show and therefore makes only limited sense, especially as a stand-alone movie.  Broadly speaking, this is the last days of humanity.  The Angels have all been defeated, but there is still a threat.  The mysterious organizations which control the world in this story are now at war with one another, and poor Shinji Ikari must somehow once again be the last hope of humanity.  Except this may turn out to mean that he has to help humanity give up its corporeal forms and become something altogether different.  NERV headquarters is under attack, and one by one, all the people Shinji has come to love are dying.  As always, whatever answers there are to be found are in Shinji's own head, and Shinji doesn't want anything to do with it.  However, no one else can possibly do what needs to be done, though Asuka gives it her level best, finally coming to terms with her own personal demons in the process.  Then again, she's always been stronger than Shinji.

The world of [i]Evangelion[/i] is a dark and complicated one.  It doesn't propose to answer any deep philosophical questions; one character asks if they are doing the right thing in helping Shinji, and her superior says, "How should I know?"  They think they're doing what's best, probably, but they have no real way of knowing until they see what the results are.  Pretty much all the characters in the series, except those members of those shadowy cabals, are flying blind.  Few of them have any idea what the long-term results of their actions will be.  They are all just hoping that it will be what's right, but few if any of them have enough information to be sure of it.  It was much easier when they were fighting Angels; a giant mysterious creature taking out entire cities is not a philosophically complicated enemy.  There is no doubt there about whether it's right or wrong.  It's attacking, and you defend.  But helping humanity to overcome the tyranny of flesh?  That's a bit trickier.

Shinji is afraid that everything he does hurts people, and so he would rather just not do anything.  It's not an uncommon philosophy, for all that, and it's not hard to see how he reached that point.  It's not made clear, but Shinji has not had a pleasant time of it of late.  Yes, he's probably saved untold lives, but it isn't healthy for the people around him.  It's not his fault, not mostly, but he can't help seeing it as such.  If he were better, stronger, smarter, faster--if he were the son his father wants.  But his father is evil, one of those shadowy sorts, and so you don't really want to be the kind of son he wants.  So Shinji is torn, and the world is collapsing around him.  He is not a happy person, and he misses the quiet innocence he was able to have before he got caught up in the whole thing.  He gets called a wimp, but I really do think he's a sympathetic character if you try to see the world from his perspective.  I don't think most of us would do much better, when it comes to that.

The world of [i]Evangelion[/i] is not one of those fictional worlds you'd like to live in.  It is a world of confusion, pain, and doubt, a world where God has abandoned His creation.  I'm not sure there's any character in it I would want to be, even leaving aside the various ends they come to.  This is one of those rare stories where backstory equals showing gaping psychological wounds, and I've got enough of those of my own to want to take on those of a fictional character.  Each one, at the end, faces a demon and either takes it in or finally overcomes it, but the point is that they all had demons in there to face or overcome in the first place.  In fact, I think that the implication is that it's that very psychological scar tissue which shapes the world, which in fact makes us human.  However, the movie doesn't come down on the idea of whether being human is a good thing or not.  There might be something better beyond humanity, but the only way to find that out is to pass through, which might be terrible.

Unnecessary, made only to pander to the fan base who sent Anno death threats for making a shitty series finale, and damaging to Evangelion as a result. Plus half the film is just trippy for the sake of trippy, plus the ending sucked.

I love Evangelion, but it was still not the ending I was hoping for. Too open ended, and many things from the series were left unresolved. Still, the fight between Unit 2 and the mass production units was unforgettable.

Absolutely horrible. Am very glad that I started this series from the remade and far superior new movies that vastly deter from this pretentious mess of senseless and brainless philosophy. It's ideas are blatantly obvious but feel the need to be as confusing and contrarian as possible. Kubrick would wipe his ass with this trite and I feel so sorry for original fans of the series in the 90s that had to settle for this atrocity as resolution. The star and a half is for its admittedly beautiful artwork, however.

The Hollywood blockbuster version of the French New Wave final episodes and a fitting end to the story with many satisfying moments, a suitably huge and unnerving ending, peek at how the series could have been free of standard and budget concerns, and, of course, a ton of fan service... much of it thoroughly disturbing. Whereas the final episodes of the show were abstract and elusive, submerging completely into Shinji's shattered psyche, the film focuses on the external world, intense and at times sickening, while remaining abstract and elusive. The entire first half is so fun to watch, especially Asaka's glorious bloodbath, you almost forget it's both visually and psychologically horrific. In the end the film's mix of Freudian and Jungian psychology, Buddhist philosophy, Christian iconography, shock imagery and metafictional commentary prove little more than postmodern intentional ambiguity. In other words: weird for the sake of weird, albeit effective weirdness.

This movie makes me angry. I love it, but at the same time it is one of the most frustrating movies to sit through on Earth. I will give credit where it's due, it is a vast improvement over the last to episodes of the series (not that those were bad, per se, but they don't reveal anything outside of the character's minds). Also, it is visually stunning, with some amazing animation. However, that doesn't keep it from being the most perplexing and surreal piece of cinematography that I have ever witnessed. The first half of the film is fairly standard storytelling, apart from some lengthy monologues by Misato to Shinji. There are some really cool action sequences, and the usual religious symbolism, but I still can't help but feel that Anno was trying to screw over his fans with the second half. For the most part the second half of the movie is just a higher-budget remake of episode 26. Some of the things that the characters say are far beyond what most people, not just fans, will be able to absorb without re-watching it three or four more times. At one point, it cuts into some live action shots, including one segment with a crowd at a movie theater. Also, I have heard that there are debates over what the final scene even means! If you can catch all of the narrative curve-balls, this movie should be a good watch, but I still can't shake the feeling that Anno is metaphorically raping all the characters, and even making fun of his fans.

Evangelion is about loneliness. All the characters have very diverse personalities, but once you get to know them better you realize that they're all hollow and lonely people. It's that brutal honesty about how people? really are behind their masks that makes it so good.
A fantastic philosophical movie, in which you can always find new things.

End of Evangelion presumably takes place after the 24th original Shin Seiki Evangelion TV series as an alternate ending and it delivers it perfectly in this masterpiece. The final angel had been killed and the 'hero' Shinji is regretting his decision. This is definitely the answer to the many fans outraged at episodes 25 and 26 concluding the series. The emotional impact of the series is quite amazing bringing an element of each characters mental breakdowns. Watch it with an open mind and expect to be amazed and how the ending finally gets pieced together.

Almost everything the end of the series should have been. Only thing regrettable is that half of its fans ended up hating this series for having been confused by all the philosophy it ended up holding. For that, I think it could have made the philosophy and complicated backstory more accessible.

One of the best animated films I've ever seen visually or plot wise. Also one of most amazing mind blowing insane endings in my opinion up there with 2001 or Mulholland Drive. Really a must-see, although to get the emotional impact of this film you really need to see the tv series.

After Evangelion fans stormed the animation studio of Gainax demanding a "better" ending to the series, Hideaki Anno made this reimagining of the last two episodes of the series that results in almost the entire beloved cast being killed off and the world being destroyed. While it certainly has it's brilliant moments (particularly in the first half, before the literal and figurative disintegration), the overbearing grimness is just hard to shake off. What's more, the film is actually trying to communicate a message of love, but it's lost amidst the brutality. If you're a fan of the series than by all means watch this, but it's hard now to say that the TV series vaguely optimistic ending was a far better fit.
If you have watched entire NGE series this revision of the ending is a glorious, brutal and fitting finish to the best anime of all time.

Death. The moment where things hold firm and the dusk of reality swoops over you.

Rebirth. The dawning of life anew, the chance to see things and learn in veiled perspective of the metaphorical.  

These are the two halves of EoE. 

Evangelion seems to be misinterpreted all the time, there are religious parallels and analogies scattered throughout the entirety of the film, but the real meaning of it lies deeper under the skin. 

It's about Shinji Ikari. Asuka. Rei. Misato. And you. The resolution to be happy in the bleakest of times, and the resolution to have resolution.

One of my favorite movies ever. This is the breaking point. You'll either think this movie is the most genius thing you've ever seen (if not upon first viewing, then usually it's the second to get a more open view point of the film), or you'll hate it for doing what it does. It likes to alienate those few who can't handle it. It's as a friend said to me: "Watching this movie is like staring into a black pit at the edge of the world...then living to tell the tale." But if you can overcome it, it'll make you all the more strong.

I Love And Hate This Film For So Many Reasons That I Won't Have Enough Space To Discuss It...It's Really Something You Have To See To Believe It's A Living Nightmare But An Interesting One...I Don't Understand It Much But It Gets Better Everytime I Watch It.
Good, but very depressing.

For me personally, Neon Genesis Evangelion is the end all - be all of Japanese animated films. In the mid-90s, the director came up with an idea, ran with it, and by the late-90s (and still today, but more so) he was famous (sometimes for the wrong reasons) and rolling in Yen. Some people were not happy with the ending the series of the show gave us. Personally, while it was not action filled, it represented the ending that I was looking forward to. I liked the 'Mind Trip' scenes because it let us delve into the character's minds a little more.

Ultimately, this movie was amazing (dispite Anno making it out of spite for the fans who despised him after the original ending... and don't get me started on the death threat). and I could not have asked for more.
Although it boosts great animation and provides a far more conclusive ending than the series; This movie while leave you feeling confused, very confused.
Made me want to hate, love and feel cold toward life all at the same time. So, very exhausting. That's literally all I got. That and the first half is way better than the second.

The alternate ending to the series "Neon Genesis Evangelion" is one on a whole different level. Whereas the television 2 episode finale ended on a small whimper, this one went beyond normal standards and left us with something complex and ambiguous.

Divided into two parts, the difference easily seen. In the first half, SEELE sends forces to kill everyone at NERV and to take control of the Evangelions, but Shinji is in a depressive state and Asuka is in a coma.

Asuka then awakens and battles her way through enemy forces, while Shinji must make the call to his final destiny. As the battle finishes, the first part ends.

The overly complex and hyper subtle second half begins. All sorts of grotesque and bizarre imagery occurs, and side characters attempt to keep you up to speed. The outcome is a very ambiguous and a very philosophical end to the series, one where discussion is necessary and multiple viewings may help.

The creator had some balls to end it with his own artistic vision, and to not dilute his vision at any cost. The result is splitting the fan base in two, some loving it and others loathing it.

I kind of liked it, its mystifying but also strangely satisfying in some ways. It all depends on what you take from it, and all that matters.

Fans were dissastisfied with the concluding two episodes of NEON GENESIS EVANGELION, so Hideaki Anno and Gainax crafted this feature as a replacement for them.  Advertised as the true finale to the EVANGELION series, it only marginally lives up to its hype.  This is a nasty, mean-spirited, narcissistic, gloomy, and downright depressing film, with characters dying left and right and an even more unstable focus than even the original final two episodes.  The film turns even more incoherent in its last half hour, which devolves into looped live-action footage, flickering screencaps from episodes, monologues, hateful verbal attacks, and flash-cuts of graphic images.  While this latter half makes for an interesting artistic style, it gets in the way of both the storytelling and even fails to provide a satisfying conclusion.  But the biggest problem of the film is that the lead character, Shinji, doesn't do ANYTHING.  He simply sits around, wallowing in self-pity, whining and angsting while his friends disappear right before his eyes.  I don't know if this film is a case of director Hideaki Anno exorcising his personal demons or making a vicious attack against the world, but either way, THE END OF EVANGELION is very unpleasant, chaotic and confusing throughout.  I can only wonder how the ending for REBUILD OF EVANGELION will turn out compared to this....

Ah End of Evangelion how you truly provided an adequate ending for Neon Genesis Evangelion. Not to say that the animated episodes were bad or anything, but although it provided excellent details on characters and their development it left us waiting for what actually happened in the real world.

End of Evangelion though mainly focuses on the real world and what is happening in terms of Seele and Nerv. The three children take a backseat in terms of the story for awhile due to events that occurred prior to the start of the movie (before episode 24 in the anime).  However as if to provide some evangelion action, all three do get into some sort of action with their Evas and my favorite character even gets to let loose and let go. The battle animations were fluid, suspenseful, gripping, and action packed.  Certainly something to die for.

Though as if driven by a need to cut costs from the use of such intense battles, a bit of the movie though goes into the realm of dreams and psychology.  I have to admit that at times what the characters say and think is something otherworldly. Though in reflection it makes sense as it seems to be statements made on the reflection of the characters on their life, the meaning that they found in their life, and truly making an attempt to accomplish and achieve that which they want.  After enduring the moments that require some concentration the movie brings it back with some excellent action and a thrilling finale. Though with the costs in mind the movie ends rather abruptly.

Certainly it is a movie that deserves to be checked out and should prepare people well for when Evangelion 4.0 comes out to presumably close out the entire series in the way that it needs to be done.  Though this movie certainly closes it well too.

This isn't really a review of this particular movie as much as it is a recommendation for the whole series. Outside of Miyazaki movies and faint memories of DBZ on Toonami, I have never been a big anime fan. I had heard a lot about Evangelion over the course of a few years and one day on a whim I threw it on my Netflix queue. Little did I know that I was about to begin watching what could possibly be the best TV series of all time. The story of Evangelion boils down to a young boy's journey as Earth's savior. The show starts out as an often humorous and action packed show about robot's fighting monsters (referred to as angels) and then turns into a deeply spiritual and psychological show when we see the mental processes of one person literally absorbing the psyche of the entire human race and becoming a sort of god who has to choose the fate of humanity (this movie serves as a recap of the mental process covered in the series as well as a window into what happens to earth physically as all of this is going on. It also covers humanities eventual fate, something that is distinctly not clear in the actual series finale). So while the majority of anime still sits besides a line of nerdiness/badness I wish to never cross, Neon Genesis Evangelion changed my perception on the genre completely.Check it out, it could seriously change your life.

A brutally tragic ending to one of the best anime tv series ever created.  This is the most creative way to end up a TV series I've ever seen and yes you should watch the show, which is only a short 24 episodes, and the first movie, Neon Genesis Evangelion: Death and Rebirth, before watching this movie.

There is no possible way to give a description about the story because it is WAY too complicated and anything I could say would probably be a spoiler so I'll start with character development. Each character is developed perfectly and this movie doesn't have that much dialogue.  The biggest piece that stuck out to me was how a lot of the character's strove for redemption. Lots of them, including Gendo, Shinji and Asuka, had minor goals that either related to the main plot or were some personal mental insecurity that needed to be fixed.  To me that marked a character being fully developed having completed a  *life goal* or fixing a flaw in their behavior.  It was just beautiful to see on screen how almost all characters were important.

The action was also amazing in The End of Evangelion.  There were only a few brief clips throughout, but there was one part in particular that was breath taking.  you could feel the character's pain as he/she battled on against  a large number of foes.

The action however was not the focus of this movie, the symbolism and drama were.  Honestly this movie felt like an animated David Lynch movie were symbolic scenes took up most of the movie.  It was very cool to see and it provides great re-watchability. You can pick out something new every time.  The next big thing this movie had going for it was the disturbing drama, and when I say disturbing I mean disturbing.  Lots of the main characters and even the real story behind this movie are just messed up this is by no means a *happy movie*.  There are lots of moments with grotesque violence and there is a good question asked to the audience that I won't write out because it's a spoiler.

In any case this is a great great great great movie and everyone should probably at least see it once, After Watching The Show! The End of Evangelion takes bold steps even some live action movies are scared of taking and it definitely stands it's ground when compared to something like say the Dark Knight. In all the End of Evangelion is a brilliant masterpiece of a movie and should be up there with  Miyazaki films as the greatest animated movies of all time.

An excellent finale to an excellent series. I was one of the few that was fine with the last two episodes, but the new ending presented in the movie stands head and shoulders about the previous one. The Freudian imagery is much more apparent, as well as the pseudo-Christian undertones. The series did an excellent job at building up an interesting world, and "End" did a brilliant job at tearing it down. Much more violent than the series, which gives it a suitably dark feel. When reality itself is dissected, bent, warped, and destroyed in fiction, you can't help but stand in awe. "End" evokes that feeling beautifully.

NGE is a true landmark in anime history, and End of Evangelion carries on with that feeling of amazement. This movie is the next chapter after the series, so it's recommended that you watch the entire series first, but the only complaint that I have with the movie is that it take a huge leap. One minute Shinji finds happiness, and the next he's depressed once again. One minute Asuka hates him, and in this movie they're boyfriend and girlfriend. Just a bit comfusing.
