[i]Neon Genesis Evangelion[/i] was a popular Japanese anime series that ran for 26 episodes, but fans of the show did not respond well to the last two episodes. The episodes in question used minimal animation to communicate the psychology of the characters into a mental ending. As a result, director Hideaki Anno decided to redo episodes 25 and 26 in the form of a theatrical feature.
 
For those who have not seen the TV series, let me bring you up to speed. An underground organization called NERV is using organic robots called Evangelions to do battle with the supernatural beings known as Angels. The Evangelions are piloted by three teenagers named Shinji, Auska and Rei. Shinji, after killing a close friend who turned out to be an Angel, is currently in a depression. Auska is in a intensive care after the last battle. Rei is currently being used as a spiritual and disposable tool of NERV. Misato, the guardian of Shinji, is starting to lose faith and becoming angry with Shinji's attitude. Gendo, Shinji's father and leader of NERV, is cooking up something that will change humanity in the basement of NERV with Rei.
 
The story picks up from there with NERV being attacked by U.N. forces now armed with nine Evangelions at their disposal. Misato is hauling around a moping Shinji while the employees of NERV are ruthlessly gunned down. Auska quickly comes to her senses when put into her Evangelion and attacks the U.N. military. Rei and Gendo are currently trying to revive a crucified Angel located in the basement named Lilith. Auska fails in her attack, Lilith rises from the ground and Shinji forces himself into his Evangelion to fight the Lilith. At this point, everything literally falls apart with many symbolic images, dream sequences, sensory overloads and discussions of uncomfortable situations. This all leads up the to feature quality and visually stunning destruction of mankind.
 
How could this possibly be considered two episodes of a TV series? Apparently, the director thinks so and I think that is the movie's biggest flaw. Even with such brilliant writing, direction and feature quality animation, director Hideaki Anno still feels the need to include title cards and closing credits to signal when "episode 25" has ended and "episode 26" begins. Putting those concerns aside, the film has some other flaws. In the scene where Lilith rises to the sky, there are many symbolic images that appear in the sky...for no reason. Yes, I understand the meaning behind the many symbols, but WHY do they show up? The only purpose these images serve is to fill the sky, act as a reference and confuse. They are pretty to look at, but I just wish they did more.
 
However, there is some symbolism in the film that works with the scene and isn't painfully obvious. Take for instance a staged scene of Shinji's childhood with visual elements relating to the womb and the desire to create and destroy. There is also some live-action footage of everyday life in Japan and an empty movie theater that works well as a reflection on life. Some of the scenes from Shinji's subconcious reveal him coming to terms with uncomfotable subjects. This includes Misato's sex life and how Shinji ejaculated on Auska in a coma. Scenes like these, despite being unbearable, are interesting to see how they play out and how Shinji responds to them.
 
And, yet, all these elements never really seem to connect. Don't get me wrong, though, they all work on their own level. It just seems like all these different emotions, feelings and understandings are disjointed into a mess of visual interpretation. Maybe this was done intentionally to act on a subconcious level or maybe it was done to overload the audience with information until they were confused enough into calling this movie an acid trip. I am not sure.
 
One element I have no complaint on is the animation. From the cold opening of the lake to the last apocalyptic enviornment, it's all top quality. Some of the best animation is in Auska's action sequence when she battles the U.N. military. Scenes such as Auska's Evangelion using a battleship as a shield and clashing metal weapons with the enemy Evas really gives a sense of scale and weight. In terms of being an apocalyptic movie, the director is able to perfectly convey that uneasy feeling of everything coming to an end. In fact, the scenes where the U.N. soldiers are slaughtering NERV employees are more horrific than the apocalypse.
 
[i]End of Evangelion [/i]is a movie that could've and should've been able to stand on it's own. Sadly, due to specific direction and writing, it remains an interesting movie trapped in the TV-based-movie genre. I don't regret seeing the film as it makes for some great subjects to talk about, but I can't quite recommend it because of the questionable symbolism, arrangement of subject matter and the fact that it is not a stand-alone movie. Fans and viewers of the TV series praise [i]End of Evangelion[/i] as it is most certainly an eye-opener. Those who have not seen the show will view this film as a confusing acid trip of psychology, philosophy and religion.

I've got a small business project going on the side right now (as though I don't have enough going on already!), and here is an excerpt from an email from one of my collaboraters after she recently discovered my blog:
     
 "so how close are you to your online persona? what would you actually pay us to NOT get printed no less than 250 cards with "Rockin' Tim - Business Development Manager" plus your blogsite address as contact information (given that having a mobile phone number is obviously a travesty of civil liberties on a scale that only you and xxx understand...)"
     
     And if you've read this journal at all, you'll of course not be surprised to hear that this got me thinking.... how close [i]am[/i] I to my online persona??
     
     [img]http://www.downes.ca/ed_radio/microphone.jpeg[/img]
     
 It's an interesting question (at least to me!)... the online persona is to a large extent an extension of my radio persona from when I was doing college radio. That's where the name 'Rockin' Tim' was invented. The story there is that I was doing a blues show one night, and I talked about how all the Blues guys had great nicknames, and how I didn't have one but if I did it would be something silly like Rockin' Tim. Despite the fact that the show was from midnight to 2:30 am, the next day no fewer than three people saw me and said 'hey! it's Rockin' Tim' so I decided that if people responded to it that strongly, I oughta stick with it. So for the rest of my radio career that was my name.
     
 Doing radio was big part of my transformation from incredibly shy, barely socially functional introvert into an outgoing on the surface able to somewhat function within society introvert, and in some ways the radio persona facilitated this. So the persona kind of represented a part of me that wasn't even really an actual part of me yet. If that makes any sense...
     
 I've always thought that "Rockin' Tim" was a reasonable facsimile of "Tim"... but on the other hand, my best friends at uni never really liked the persona, and the only people that called me Rockin' Tim outside of the radio station were people that didn't know me that well. So maybe it wasn't...
     
 All of which brings us back to the original question. And the answer is - I don't know. I think that people that only know me through this journal wouldn't be too surprised if they met me in person (disappointed maybe, but that's a whole other issue!). They might be surprised by just how much of a bookworm I am... as the people that know me through academics are surprised when they see this blog. But I think both blog-Tim and academic-Tim make up complementary parts of the whole me...
     
 Sooooooooooooo, all of this brings us to Neon Genesis Evangelion. Which looks at a lot of similar issues - what is your identity, how do people connect with each other, what would a life without pain be like, et cetera. All within the context of what on the surface is another anime big mechanical robot battle show. It's got all the stuff that you'd expect with the latter: big fights, lots of hot anime babes, enormous hidden conspiracies, more fights, more babes, and so on. But it also has a huge dose of existentialism, biblical symbolism and navel gazing. There's a [i]whole lot[/i] going in this show, and it would certainly reward multiple viewings. Overall, the whole thing is kind of like if Jim Jarmusch got signed up to direct the next Star Wars movie, and he was working from a script by Camus. Or something like that.
     
 The box set ends in a bit of a fizzle, but I really like it. This is the version that ran as a tv series in '95. However, fans in Japan apparently [i]hated[/i] the ending, which led to two tries at wrapping things up more conventionally. The first try is called Neon Genesis Evangelion: Death and Rebirth, and from all accounts, it is not worth the time. The only new footage in it is also the first half of NGE: The End of Evangelion, which then goes on to a huge apocalyptic ending, where several of the loose ends are wrapped up. Curiously, philosophically it ends up at exactly the same place that the original series does, it just gets there in a completely different way.
     
 All in all, NGE is messy, sometimes sloppy, and utterly fascinating. The whole thing runs for about 12 hours, but in the end, I thought it was worth the time. For it to be worth your time, you've got to be pretty interested in the philosophical stuff - if you're just looking for action, there are probably better things around. But if you want action and thinking, this is the way to go. There are parts of it that don't make any sense at all, but I've really enjoyed trying to figure the whole thing out. Oh, and also, it has a penguin...
     
     [img]http://www.absoluteanime.com/eva/pen_pen.jpg[/img][img]http://sfirk.canalblog.com/Pen2.jpg[/img]
     
 Getting back to my journal, the character in it that probably least resembles his online persona is Zamboni! In person, he's a great cat - especially around me and Nancy. But he's very shy around other people. So when you get to see pictures of him here, you get to see sides of him that you'd probably never get to see if you saw him in person...
     
     [img]http://www.fieldornithologists.com/nancyandtim/zambonibag.jpg[/img]
    
    Oh, and I want the title on my business cards to be:
    
    King

 THIS is how the series, and arguably the greatest anime of all times should have ended. Not in a whimper, but ina BANG! A bang, with a forray of psychological and philosophical elements, so profuse-it's just perfect[img]http://images.rottentomatoes.com/images/user/smilies/smile.gif[/img]
   
 The last two episodes to Neon Genesis Evangelion were good... But a let down from the heights witnessed throughout the other 23 episodes. End of Evangelion makes amends, and never dissapoints, at least on a clear asthetic level. It follows suite from the series' greatest episodes and explodes them onto the big screen. Plot twists are rampant. Loose ends are explained. Action is undefiably great. And more importantly, the entire series comes full circle. It couldn't have ended any other way. Fans of the serie will, of course, eat this up. Anyone who hasn't seen the entire series, and then sees this first, is really missing out in the full experience. 
   
 Though the end of End, is vague and maybe confusing. All of the pieces are there. Enough, to find the important answers. And enough missing, to inspire some interesting speculation.

The End of Evangelion (2002)  Im so fucked up.  - Shinji Ikari, Pilot, EVA Unit One

When the Japanese anime television series Neon Genesis Evangelion ended in 1996, legions of faithful watchers simply freaked.  The series had ended with the defeat of the Angels, who had come to free Adam, an Angel captured by humanity (and quite possibly God Himself).  Humanity defeated the Angels using Adam knock-offs known as Evangelions - giant living creatures piloted by gifted teenagers with enormous emotional problems.  In the final television episode, the Evangelion pilots were left in such a state of mental chaos that fans went crazy.  The director of the sexually potent series (and this movie) Hidaeki Anno even received death threats if he didnt take care of the mess he had left.

I purchased the 8 DVD set of the television series, and after watching with growing fascination (and frustration), I could understand how the fans felt.  When the last disc had spun to its end, I wasnt sure if I was badly confused or if I needed therapy.  Then, in 2002, came the movie The End of Evangelion, containing two additional episodes, which I had only just learned about through the good fortune of having Grand SACHI as an RT friend.

You kill or you die. Shigeru Aoba, NERV Lieutenant

I ended up watching the film twice, and then spent time going through parts of the film frame-by-frame (the detail is amazing!).  Even knowing the storys potential, and armed with Grand SACHIs warning, I still wasnt prepared for the turn that the story would take, and the hard-core violence that resulted.  Uniquely horrific, brilliantly constructed, and nearly incomprehensible, The End of Evangelion is a cinematic mind-fuck.  It was like sex directly wired into your brain, only you don't have any control over it.  Don't worry.  You'll survive, I think.
